Januvia and pancreatic cancer

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎04-24-2013 08:15 PM

I am freaking out again about the research that has been published about Januvia and its connection to pancreatic cancer--studies showing that using Januvia or Byetta may lead to a greater chance of getting pancreatic cancer. Who else has read about this and are you concerned as I am? First metformin is linked to Alzheimer's disease and now Januvia and Byetta are linked to pancreatic cancer. Should I stop taking Januvia?

Report Inappropriate Content

‎04-24-2013 08:36 PM

That's exactly why I went too a new Endo doc for this exact discussion. I had 2 bouts of pancreatitis 30+ years ago and have been on januvia for 2 years then Byetta was added and I was really worried. My new doc took me off those and put me on the new drug Invokana. That also has some side effects but apparently not the pancreas. Will see how this goes. Next step insulin if this doesn't keep my sugar in line.

Metformin. 1000 x2
Glipizide 15mg before breakfast
Victoza 1.2
Norvasc 10 mgs
Losartan 100 mg am
Choloeast
Baby aspirin

Re: Januvia and pancreatic cancer

Options

‎04-24-2013 08:48 PM

pstewart51 wrote:

I am freaking out again about the research that has been published about Januvia and its connection to pancreatic cancer--studies showing that using Januvia or Byetta may lead to a greater chance of getting pancreatic cancer. Who else has read about this and are you concerned as I am? First metformin is linked to Alzheimer's disease and now Januvia and Byetta are linked to pancreatic cancer. Should I stop taking Januvia?

Take a good look at those articles to decide how freaked out you should be.

 

If Januvia doubles the risk of pancreatic cancer, that wounds pretty scary for sure. But look at it this way--if the rate of pancreatic cancer is 1 in 10,000 people, then with Januvia it is 2 in 10,000.  And that means that you increase your risk by 1 in 10,000 people, or you have a .01% higher chance of pancreatic cancer.  That sounds a lot less scary than doubling the risk, doesn't it?

 

Of course I made up those numbers because the papers are not in front of me, but generally that is how the calculations work. Depending on how you state it, it can look very scary, or actually not that scary at all. Now of course even a slight increase is an increase, and being aware of that is important. But understanding how the numbers work can give you more insight into how worried you should be.

Morris

Diagnosed Type 2, with an A1c of 11.4 in 2003; averaging a 5.0 A1c since then with diet, exercise and Glipizide XL + meds for blood pressure and cholesterol.  A bit dated, but scroll down on this page if you want to know more ...

Until studies have more conclusive data, I decided to go on insulin rather than adding januvia.

My Dr said it was safe, but I wasn't convinced.

And, I'm very happy with the route I selected thus far.

Greg

Re: Januvia and pancreatic cancer

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎04-25-2013 10:34 AM

I took Januvia for about 6 years, because I couldn't tolerate metformin.  It was great stuff!  My BG levels were good and I had no side effects at all.

 

In October 2012, I went to the emergency room in tremendous pain and they discovered a tumor in my pancreas about the size of a tennis ball.  In December, they removed most of my pancreas, all of my spleen, and an adrenal gland.  I just finished 3 months of chemo.  Now I just have to wait and see if this monster returns.  Meanwhile, I'm adjusting to dealing with insulin.

 

I had a long discussion with the oncologist about Januvia and the tumor.  His input was that pancreatic cancer is pretty rare and the tumor I had was rare even for pancreatic cancer.  They're just not seeing a line of diabetic patients coming in with pancreatic tumors and a history of using Januvia.  What Morris was describing as far as risk is a pretty good explanation of how the chances of getting cancer might increase.  I had the same discussion with my endochronologist (who is really good at keeping up with current studies) and his input was the same.

 

Pancreatic cancer is bad stuff.  Well, ALL cancer is bad stuff, but pancreatic is particularly nasty.  The overall survival rate is about 6% and that number hasn't improved in the last 40 years (unlike the survival rates for many other cancers).  If you have a risk of it (e.g., having it in the family history), then by all means do everything you can do to minimize your chances of getting it.

 

As for the personal choice of using Januvia, remember that all drugs have some risk that there will be adverse effects.  With metformin, explosive diarhea is certainly a common and difficult side effect.  You should always try to understand - and discuss with your doctor! - any potential risk and to watch carefully for the first signs that problems are occurring.

 

 

 

 

Type 2 - complicated by surgery for pancreatic cancer

ellyn3 wrote:

I can relate to that pain.  Was in the hospital twice with pancreatitis. I've never had pain like that ( screaming and yelling for a long time ), it was worse than my rotator cuff surgery a few years ago.  That's why I decided to get off all drugs that have that warning.  Will try the Invokana for awhile and see how that goes and if there are problems I'll do insulin  

Yeah, they asked me at the front desk of the ER to rate my pain from 1 to 10.  I asked, "What level makes you cry?"  They gave me morphine and it might as well been a baby aspirin.  Then they did dilaudin and that did cut the pain to a manageble level.  (A little bit more and I probably could have done surgery on myself!)

 

 

Type 2 - complicated by surgery for pancreatic cancer
